Literature Review: Model-based clustering represents a sophisticated approach to the clustering problem, leveraging statistical models to partition data into meaningful groups. This method stands in contrast to heuristic clustering techniques by providing a probabilistic framework that accounts for uncertainty in cluster assignments and offers a systematic way to determine the number of clusters. The foundation of model-based clustering lies in the use of mixture models, where each component of the mixture corresponds to a cluster, and the data are assumed to be generated from a mixture of probability distributions (Fraley & Raftery, 2002). This approach not only facilitates a deeper understanding of the underlying structure of the data but also allows for the application of rigorous statistical methods for parameter estimation and model selection. The Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm is a cornerstone in the estimation of parameters in model-based clustering, iteratively refining the estimates to maximize the likelihood of the observed data (Dempster, Laird, & Rubin, 1977). Recent advancements have extended the applicability of model-based clustering to a wide range of data types, including high-dimensional data, time series, and network data, by incorporating more complex models and leveraging Bayesian inference techniques for enhanced flexibility and robustness (McLachlan & Peel, 2000). Bayesian approaches to model-based clustering, in particular, have gained popularity for their ability to incorporate prior information and to provide a coherent framework for uncertainty quantification (Fruhwirth-Schnatter, 2006). The development of specialized software packages has further democratized access to model-based clustering methods, enabling researchers and practitioners to apply these techniques to their data with relative ease (Scrucca, Fop, Murphy, & Raftery, 2016). Despite its many advantages, model-based clustering is not without challenges. The selection of an appropriate model and the determination of the number of clusters remain critical issues, with various criteria and algorithms proposed to address these problems (Celeux & Soromenho, 1996). Moreover, the computational complexity of model-based clustering can be a limiting factor, especially for large datasets or complex models. Nevertheless, ongoing research continues to push the boundaries of model-based clustering, exploring new models, algorithms, and applications that promise to further enhance its utility and impact (Bouveyron, Celeux, Murphy, & Raftery, 2019). In summary, model-based clustering offers a powerful and flexible framework for data analysis, grounded in statistical theory and supported by a growing body of methodological developments and software tools. As the field evolves, it is likely to remain at the forefront of clustering research, providing valuable insights into the structure of complex datasets across a wide range of disciplines.
